This method being synchronized meant that only one thread can enter this static method at a time. Because of this, tests have been failing lately just by getting stuck waiting in line to enter this method. In most cases, this method is called during each test setup, so it is called a lot.
By removing the synchronization, the SDK test side doesn't slow itself down in making these requests, but IoT Hub often responds slower because of it, or responds with a throttle. The added throttleResistantTestRule covers the latter, and using infinite read timeouts covers the former. As a result, our tests scale better if we ever upgrade to an S2 for testing, but still work against an S1
Same as above. This synchronization placed a bottle neck on the SDK tests, so I'm removing it
This test rule makes each test run (base.evaluate() runs the test) until it passes or until it fails with a non-throttling exception
This exception gets thrown by any HTTP request (registryManager.addDevice, deviceMethod.invokeMethod, etc.)

With the throttle resistant test rule, we can no longer use this method of checking for an exception upon executing some code. If the test encounters a 429 exception, that 429 gets compared to this GatewayTimeoutException, and since they don't match, the test throws an AssertionFailedException. Once that AssertionFailedException bubbles up to the throttle resistant test rule, the test won't be re-run since the test didn't seem to fail from a 429.
Making each test have their own registry manager instead of sharing one static instance

Note that only the read timeout will be infinite. The tests will still timeout if they fail to connect to iothub. With this change, they just won't throw an exception if iothub takes a while to finish the operation and return the http response
